conclusion: To determine the proportionality constant k, analyze the motion of the oil droplets under different conditions using given information about velocities and forces.
Two spherical oil droplets, A and B, are located on the same vertical line between two plates with a voltage applied.
When no voltage is applied, both droplets A and B fall with a uniform velocity v0, and the net force on each droplet is zero.
The gravitational force mg equals the air resistance km^(1/3)v0, leading to k = m^(2/3)g/v0.
When voltage U is applied, an electric field E = U/d is created, and droplet B moves upward with a uniform velocity v1.
The electric force qE on droplet B equals mg + km^(1/3)v1, leading to qU/d = mg + km^(1/3)v1.
Droplet B rises through a distance h2 in time t, giving v1 = h2/t.
Droplet A continues to fall with velocity v0, giving v0 = h1/t.
Substitute v0 and v1 into the expressions for k to get k = m^(2/3)gt/h1.
Substitute k = m^(2/3)gt/h1 into the equation for the electric force to find q = mgd/U (1 + h2/h1).
The proportionality constant k is m^(2/3)gt/h1.
